section.title: Software Defined Networking
section.para: Software Defined Networking (SDN) is the separation of the data plane and control plane. SDN has become a popular method of managing and controlling packet flows within networks. SDN uses overlays or directly controlled layer 2 devices to determine flow paths, and as such presents challenges to a cloud environment. Some designers may wish to run their controllers within an OpenStack installation. Others may wish to have their installations participate in an SDN-controlled network.

section.title: Challenges
section.para: SDN is a relatively new concept that is not yet standardized, so SDN systems come in a variety of different implementations. Because of this, a truly prescriptive architecture is not feasible. Instead, examine the differences between an existing or intended OpenStack design and determine where the potential conflict and gaps can be found.

section.title: Possible solutions
section.para: If an SDN implementation requires layer 2 access because it directly manipulates switches, then running an overlay network or a layer 3 agent may not be advisable. If the controller resides within an OpenStack installation, it may be necessary to build an ML2 plug-in and schedule the controller instances to connect to tenant VLANs that then talk directly to the switch hardware. Alternatively, depending on the external device support, use a tunnel that terminates at the switch hardware itself.
